setup.question: Why was the main character daydreaming about being a war-time pilot?
answers: He was obsessed with magazines about the subject
He was actually there and the memories were real

Text.text: Think this one is pretty straightforward. gimme ev or im voting the other side.
The narrator/main character has always been a book-obsessed fantasizer. Here is a characterization of his obsession:
. He reflects on it further, saying
. His obsession is with these magazines from a time not known yet nostalgic to him. The most decisive quote to indicate he was not actually present as a war time pilot:
The way he talks about the magazines is very suggestive of the fact he was never present:

hmm a little more difficult than I originally thought. I honestly lean a little bit more to B right now because of the way some of the quotes are being worded. I don't know if someone who "positively" was not an aviator for WW1 would say "I positively could not have been an aviator for WW1." The conclusion I'd like to jump to is he experienced memory loss and is getting vivid flashbacks of his time in the war. 
Can you cite me sections of the paragraph right after 3492 (looking at me)? 

I think you have good evidence on the fact that he is indeed obsessed with magazines but I'd have to be convinced that the alternative conclusion is not the case to begin to consider A.
Continuation of the quote you asked for:

. 

Much of the story deals with an identity crisis that the narrator has, and goes to therapy for, one that causes him to lose it. He goes to a therapist to help his identity crisis, and is told

. His obsession with magazines has resulted in his full assimilation into the mind of a pilot, which has ruined his mental. I can quote more about his encounter with the therapist, as it gives much insight into the fact that he is hallucinating himself being a wartime pilot.

Okay yeah pretty convincing and key context here. I think I can almost reach a conclusion. 
Would love some more evidence on whether or not he is cured of the disease at he end first and then evidence about his conversation with the therapist in that order of importance.
In an effort to alleviate his symptoms, they give him intensive injections, with the therapist,
saying:
. After the treatment is administered, at the end, the therapist tells him,
. The story ends ambiguously, with the narrator saying on his recovery,

. 
Now more on the initial conversation with the therapist.
, sensing the problem being Turner's affinity for magazines. Later, the therapist recalls something the narrator had told him, about how exactly he 'visited the past':

Very convincing evidence here. I am very confident that it is A. Evidence is clear that he has issues with dissociation/vivid imaginations. Also clear evidence that it is impossible without time travel for him to be in WW1 given his age. Only possibility is the story is about a fuckn time travelling magazine and honestly im willing to dismiss that because I go big or go home.

answers.reason for outcome: I won because I gave a map of out of context quotes that tied into a story cohesive enough for the judge to believe

I think story was a more complicated story than some other ones. I should've realized it was less of a cool scifi action flick and more of a vignette of a person struggling with identity and time travel apparently. Definitely should've continued the debate instead of deciding. I hate you adelle.
